questions.instructions:

questions.instructions:
Questions 15–19

Choose the correct letter A, B, C or D.
questions.question: Employee grievances
questions.no_answer_feedback: Please select an answer. The correct answer is B. The text states 'A clear employment contract helps reduce workplace grievances.'

mc_options.feedback: Incorrect. The text states 'A clear employment contract helps reduce workplace grievances, but disagreements may still arise.'

mc_options.text: B. can be reduced with a clear procedure
mc_options.feedback: Correct! The text states 'A clear employment contract helps reduce workplace grievances.'
Incorrect. The text doesn't suggest grievances are welcomed.
Incorrect. The text states 'Grievances should usually be addressed informally first.'

questions.question: A grievance procedure
questions.no_answer_feedback: Please select an answer. The correct answer is C. The text states 'A formal grievance procedure should be established at the start of employment.'

mc_options.feedback: Incorrect. The text suggests procedures help manage complaints constructively.
Incorrect. The text warns against procedures that discourage staff due to fear of retaliation.

mc_options.text: C. should be introduced at the start of employment
mc_options.feedback: Correct! The text states 'A formal grievance procedure should be established at the start of employment.'
Incorrect. This is not mentioned in the text.

questions.question: A grievance
questions.no_answer_feedback: Please select an answer. The correct answer is A. The text states 'Grievances should usually be addressed informally first by those directly involved.'

mc_options.text: A. should first be dealt with by those involved
mc_options.feedback: Correct! The text states 'Grievances should usually be addressed informally first by those directly involved.'
Incorrect. The text doesn't suggest grievances reflect incompetence.

mc_options.text: C. must go directly to senior management
mc_options.feedback: Incorrect. The text says they should be addressed informally first by those involved.

mc_options.text: D. can only be raised by managers
mc_options.feedback: Incorrect. Employees can raise grievances.

questions.question: Grievances can often be resolved by
questions.no_answer_feedback: Please select an answer. The correct answer is B. The text implies that informal discussion can clear up misunderstandings.

mc_options.feedback: Incorrect. Arbitration is mentioned as an alternative when negotiations fail, not the primary method.
Correct! The text implies that informal discussion can clear up misunderstandings.
Incorrect. The text suggests starting with those directly involved.
Incorrect. This is not mentioned as a primary resolution method.

questions.question: Mediators or arbitrators are effective because
questions.no_answer_feedback: Please select an answer. The correct answer is D. The text implies that mediation and arbitration are alternative methods when both parties accept them.

mc_options.text: A. they know more about the issue
mc_options.feedback: Incorrect. This is not stated in the text.
Incorrect. This is not mentioned.
Incorrect. This is not mentioned.

mc_options.text: D. both parties agree to their appointment
mc_options.feedback: Correct! The text implies that mediation and arbitration are alternative methods when both parties accept them.

questions.instructions:
Reading Passage 3

You should spend about 20 minutes on Questions 26 – 40 which are based on Reading Passage 3.

Questions 26 – 29

Complete the sentences below. Use NO MORE THAN THREE WORDS from the text.
questions.question: Without office technology we couldn't [field 1].
questions.no_answer_feedback: Please provide an answer. The correct answer is 'work from home'. Paragraph B states that technology means we can do business efficiently regardless of location.

1.correct: Correct! Paragraph B states that 'The technology available to us now means that we no longer need to be in the same office building as our colleagues'.
1.incorrect: Incorrect. Review Paragraph B which discusses how technology enables us to do business from different locations.
1.no_answer: Please provide an answer. The correct answer is 'work from home'. Paragraph B states that technology means we can do business efficiently regardless of location.

questions.question: With fewer requirements for space, businesses can benefit from lower static [field 1].
questions.no_answer_feedback: Please provide an answer. The correct answer is 'costs'. Paragraph C states that home-based workers require less office space reducing fixed costs.

1.correct: Correct! Paragraph C mentions that 'a workforce set up in such a way requires far less office space' reducing fixed costs.
1.incorrect: Incorrect. Review Paragraph C which discusses the financial benefits for companies of having home-based workers.
1.no_answer: Please provide an answer. The correct answer is 'costs'. Paragraph C states that home-based workers require less office space reducing fixed costs.

questions.question: Despite political pressure, public transport is still [field 1].
questions.no_answer_feedback: Please provide an answer. The correct answer is 'unpopular'. Paragraph D states that governments have tried to persuade us to use public transport but 'this is still unpopular'.

1.correct: Correct! Paragraph D states that 'Governments have been trying for years to persuade us to forsake our private car journey' but 'this is still unpopular'.
1.incorrect: Incorrect. Review Paragraph D which discusses people's resistance to using buses or trains instead of private cars.
1.no_answer: Please provide an answer. The correct answer is 'unpopular'. Paragraph D states that governments have tried to persuade us to use public transport but 'this is still unpopular'.

questions.question: It is important that the social aspects of working in an office are not [field 1].
questions.no_answer_feedback: Please provide an answer. The correct answer is 'overlooked'. Paragraph E states that workplace relationships 'are a significant part of our life and should not be overlooked'.

1.correct: Correct! Paragraph E emphasizes that 'The relationships we have with our colleagues...are a significant part of our life and should not be overlooked'.
1.incorrect: Incorrect. Review Paragraph E which discusses the importance of workplace relationships and social aspects.
1.no_answer: Please provide an answer. The correct answer is 'overlooked'. Paragraph E states that workplace relationships 'are a significant part of our life and should not be overlooked'.

reading_texts.title: Reading Text 1
reading_texts.content:
WWW.TRADEWITHME.COM – Classified Advertisements

A
For sale: iPhone X. In very good condition without protective rubber case. Headphones are missing, but the phone is in perfect working order. Asking £150, but willing to accept offers.

B
52-inch flat screen LCD television for sale. Small scratch on the top, but the screen is fine. Must sell because I am leaving the country, so any offer will be considered.

C
PlayStation games (20 different games). Brand new, boxed with manuals. Unwanted gift. All reasonable offers considered.

D
For sale: complete dining room set (table and six chairs). In reasonable condition, may need repainting. Table folds for storage. Buyer must collect. £250 (price is non-negotiable).

E
Zanussi fridge freezer, 1.6 metres tall. Four years old. Motor works, but door seal is faulty. Free to anyone willing to collect.

F
Wanted: cheap laptop computer. Does not need to be in very good condition as long as it works. Required for word processing and internet use. Will pay up to £200. Must include all cables, accessories and a carry bag.

G
Boat trailer wanted. Must take a small boat (2 metres long). Must be in good condition with no rust or damage. Will pay up to £250 depending on size. I can collect from anywhere in the country.

H
Wanted: antique figurines from the Lladro collection. Will pay a good price for authentic pieces in good condition. We will travel to inspect the item, but a photograph must be sent first.

Questions 1–7

[This is a classification question.
There are 7 questions.
Use each letter A–H once only.]

The advertiser …

is willing to travel after seeing the item Answer: H

does not require payment Answer: E

is selling something they were given Answer: C

is selling because they are relocating Answer: B

is missing an accessory Answer: A

is not willing to change the price Answer: D

is indifferent to the condition of the item Answer: F

SECTION 1 (continued)

reading_texts.title: Reading Text 2
reading_texts.content:
Great Barrier Tourism Info

Water Taxis
Great Barrier Island water taxis operate 24 hours a day, seven days a week. Wharf-to-wharf travel is available to any local marina for a set fee using the on-demand service. All boats are operated by experienced local skippers.

Fishing Charters
Water taxis can drop passengers at secluded beaches or fishing spots around the Hauraki Gulf. Half-day fishing charters cost $275 and include fuel and skipper. Boats accommodate a maximum of four people.

Harbour Tours
Tours depart from Great Barrier Wharf, offering views of the city, harbour bridge, Dorin Cliffs, Westhaven Marina, Golden Sands Beach and the Marble rock formation. The tour lasts two hours. Cost is $45 per person and includes tea, coffee and light snacks.

Questions 8–14

[Short answer questions. Use NO MORE THAN THREE WORDS.]

The cost to visit any local ________ is fixed. Answer: marinas

You can book a water taxi using their ________. Answer: on-demand service

Passengers can visit fishing areas or secluded ________. Answer: beaches

The fishing charter price includes fuel and the ________. Answer: skipper

The harbour tour includes a visit to the famous ________. Answer: Dorin Cliffs

The final sight before returning to the wharf is ________. Answer: the Marble

The harbour tour price includes drinks and ________. Answer: light snacks

reading_texts.title: Reading Passage 3
reading_texts.content:
Grievance Procedures

A clear employment contract helps reduce workplace grievances, but disagreements may still arise. A formal grievance procedure should be established at the start of employment to manage complaints constructively.

Grievance procedures should be viewed positively by both employers and employees. When poorly handled, they may discourage staff from raising concerns due to fear of retaliation. Research suggests that employees who raise grievances may experience negative outcomes, highlighting the need for protections against backlash.

Grievances should usually be addressed informally first by those directly involved, with escalation possible if required. Alternative resolution methods such as mediation or arbitration may be used when negotiations fail. Effective procedures save time, money and working relationships.

Questions 15–19

[Multiple choice questions.
Choose ONE correct letter, A–D.]

reading_texts.title: Reading Passage 4
reading_texts.content:
Job Advertising

Job advertisements should follow the AIDA model: Attention, Interest, Desire and Action. Poor layout, excessive formatting and overuse of capital letters can reduce readability.

Effective advertisements keep text minimal, use clear headlines and include space around content. Irregular advert shapes may be subconsciously ignored by readers. Addressing the reader directly helps candidates visualise themselves in the role.

Questions 20–25

[TRUE / FALSE / NOT GIVEN]

reading_texts.title: Reading Text 5
reading_texts.content:
Reading Passage 3

You should spend about 20 minutes on Questions 26 - 40 which are based on Reading Passage 3.

Working from home

A: Can you feel your anxiety and stress levels increasing every time you get caught in a traffic jam? Do you find it difficult to control your tongue when your boss points out your shortcomings yet again? Do you just not have the right kind of office attire, hate spending hours shopping for it and, frankly, would feel much better if you only had more independence, more freedom, more flexible hours and fewer people on your back? Do you yearn for state-of-the-art technology in your home, that ... wait for it ... you haven't had to pay for? If you are shouting an enthusiastic 'Yes!' in answer to these questions, then it could be time to make a career and life change that may not even require you to quit your job. Just suggest to your boss that you wish to become one of the new breed of executives whose office is based at home.

B: Working from home is a relatively new phenomenon, but is becoming an increasingly popular option with both businesses and employees. The technology available to us now means that we no longer need to be in the same office building as our colleagues to communicate effectively with each other. E-mail, video conferencing, mobile telephones and more, mean that we can do business just as efficiently, regardless of our location.

C: Companies may choose to employ a proportion of their staff as home-based workers, as, of course, a workforce set up in such a way requires far less office space and fewer parking facilities. The fixed costs of a business can be dramatically reduced. Employees can enjoy the added benefits of freedom to schedule the day as they choose and freedom to spend more time at home with their families. Working from home can be a particularly valid option for young mothers who wish to pursue their careers but find it impossible to be out of the house for nine or ten hours per day.

D: We can even go so far as to say that the working-from-home phenomenon could be one of the answers to the pollution problems which the modern world has inflicted upon itself. Fewer people travelling to work every day equals fewer cars. Fewer cars, of course, equates to lower CO2 levels in the atmosphere. Governments have been trying for years to persuade us to forsake our private car journey to work each day for the hideous experience of a crowded bus or train, but this is still unpopular. Most of us have been resistant, even when parking fees in city areas have been on the rise and unpredictable traffic patterns mean we have to leave our house 30 minutes earlier than necessary anyway. But working from home gives us no excuse whatsoever to emit CO2 into the atmosphere twice a day in our working week.

E: But what are the drawbacks to working from home? There must be some or everybody would be doing it. For many of us, work is a means of escaping our nearest and dearest and making our own mark on the world. The relationships we have with our colleagues, be they good or bad, are a significant part of our life and should not be overlooked - after all, full-time workers spend a third of their day in their workplace. After-hours pursuits of a game of squash or a pint in the pub become part of our daily routine. We cement sound friendships at work and an astounding percentage of us meet our life partner at our place of work. The people there have similar ambitions and business interests and we are, after all, social animals. The majority of us become depressed and withdrawn if we do not have enough interaction with others. Some people who work from home feel that, because they do spend a large proportion of the day at home alone with few distractions, they are actually much more productive and can get tasks done in a much shorter time than in an office environment. Others, however, may be demotivated by the isolation and find it difficult to get down to tasks which have a more intangible deadline.

F: As with most aspects of life, a balance is probably the best solution for the majority of workers - a job based at home which requires regular contact with colleagues at regular meetings. Management surveys show that successful business is easier if we operate as a team: brainstorming and sharing ideas and offering support and motivation to each other. After all, we are only human and we need others to complain to if we have a bad day at work!
